principles.name: Creative Owners Focus
principles.description: 'I help creative owners get back to doing what they were doing that made the business great.' Core mission focused on enabling founders to return to their strengths.

principles.name: Switzerland Neutrality Model
principles.description: 'I am Switzerland if the employee... I freely admit I am being paid by the owner, but I work for the company, and I'm going to do the... I'm going to work in the best interest of the company, not the owner.' Neutral position between owner and employees.

principles.name: Leadership Term Rejection
principles.description: 'I won't say leadership because I don't think that word means anything anymore. It's just squishy, and people just run around saying that they're practicing leadership.' Preferring concrete terms like accountability and responsibility.

principles.name: Accountability and Responsibility Over Leadership
principles.description: 'I help people become more accountable, and I help them take on more responsibility... I work to figure out who owns what in the organization and who is capable of taking on more and helping them get it.'

principles.name: Early Passion for Influence and Events
principles.description: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for being class president.' Early drive to shape outcomes and be central to important activities.

principles.name: Partner Role Model Disillusionment
principles.description: 'Very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' Success without lifestyle appeal led to career redirection.

patterns.name: Multi-Role Capability Deployment
patterns.description: Function as CFO, warehouse manager, treasurer, accountant, advisor, board member, integrator, strategist, or CEO depending on business needs.
patterns.context: Small business consulting where role flexibility allows filling multiple organizational gaps as needed.

patterns.name: Company-First Allegiance Declaration
patterns.description: Explicitly state loyalty to company interests rather than owner preferences, creating trust with employees while maintaining owner relationship.
patterns.context: Organizational consulting where employee buy-in is crucial but owner funding creates potential conflict of interest.

examples.name: Comprehensive Expertise Inventory
examples.content: Dan's mini-expertise areas include: 'Financial analysis, accounting, bookkeeping, sales tax planning, relationship building, pricing, margin analysis, inventory analysis, vendor negotiation... delegation model... clarifying roles and responsibilities. Being a sounding board and being willing to tell the owner what they want to hear, whether they want to hear it or not.'

examples.name: Switzerland Neutrality Metaphor
examples.content: Dan describes his role as 'Switzerland' to employees: 'I freely admit I am being paid by the owner, but I work for the company, and I'm going to work in the best interest of the company, not the owner, understanding that if I do something that is not in the best interest of the owner, I'll get fired.'

examples.name: Early Passion for Influence
examples.content: Dan traces his motivation back to high school: 'The passion was to be involved in influence events in effect. I don't know if it was to lead or not... I had a passion for being class president.' Early career passion was 'money and the prestige' with 'the goal was partner.'

examples.name: Partner Role Model Disillusionment
examples.content: After having children, Dan realized 'very few of the partners served as very good role models for me... they were rich, but I don't know that they were leading lives that really interested me.' This led him to leave the partnership track.
